Organs/Tissues: Human liver micro-tissue for drug metabolism and DILI (drug-induced liver injury) prediction
Physiological/Pathological: Physiological liver function, used to detect pathological toxicity responses
Cell Source: iPSC-derived hepatocytes (often from diverse donors), potentially co-cultured with non-parenchymal cells
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, core is hepatocytes; optional Kupffer cells or stellate for advanced function
Stromal Cells: Yes (stellate) if needed; not always standard
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible inclusion of Kupffer cells, but not guaranteed
Circulating Immune: No typical immune circulation in the system
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Potentially integrated with other organ chips or AI-simulated crosstalk, physically or via data synergy
Extracellular Matrix: Likely collagen or hydrogel scaffolds in microfluidic wells
Notable Features: High-throughput microfluidic array with integrated sensors, data feeding Quris Bio-AI for safety predictions
Plate/Format (Throughput): Proprietary multi-well microfluidic chip with nano-sensors, thousands of parallel tests possible
Max Culture Duration: Days to ~2 weeks for repeated dosing or metabolism tests
Readouts - Live Imaging: Limited; main readouts from integrated nano-sensors, but imaging is possible for deeper analysis
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, to measure secreted markers or drug/metabolites
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: End-of-run tissue harvest for validation; not routine in high-throughput
Readouts - Whole Tissue: If needed, can fix the micro-liver tissue for histology or IF
Readouts - TEER: No (not a barrier), measure viability/toxicity via sensors
Readouts - MEA: No, not relevant for liver; rely on biosensor + AI approach
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes (core feature: real-time sensor data for toxicity signatures)
Dead Volume: Minimal microliter-scale volume, minimal compound usage
Perfused: Yes or partial flow; microfluidic format with dynamic fluid control
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator environment, automated system ensures standard conditions
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated dosing schedules, sensor-based monitoring in real-time
model_availability: Not sold; available via Quris’s internal platform or partner collaborations

Organs/Tissues: Human cardiac microtissue for cardiotoxicity testing
Physiological/Pathological: Physiological beating heart muscle; can detect pathological arrhythmias or contractile dysfunction
Cell Source: iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes (multiple donors for genetic diversity), possibly co-cultured with cardiac fibroblasts
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (CMs + fibroblasts); no immune or endothelial
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Potential multi-organ integration or AI-driven crosstalk simulation, not physically linked by default
3D Scaffold: Yes, 3D beating micro-tissue with integrated sensors for conduction/arrhythmia
Notable Features: High-throughput sensor-based readouts of contractility & arrhythmias, used by Quris’s AI to predict cardiotoxicity
Plate/Format (Throughput): Large array of micro-wells with built-in electrodes or impedance sensors, enabling thousands of parallel tests
Max Culture Duration: Days to a couple weeks, enough to detect chronic cardiotoxicity
Readouts - Live Imaging: Possible; main routine from nano-sensors capturing beat patterns
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, if needed (cardiac injury biomarkers, etc.)
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Feasible after run, but not typical in high-throughput
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Possible for endpoint histology if a sample is singled out
Readouts - MEA: Equivalent functionality (electrical or mechanical sensors) integrated, real-time beat detection
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes (core approach: nano-sensing of beat rate, conduction, etc.)
Perfused: Microfluidic approach or partial flow for nutrient supply; no large external pump needed
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated drug additions & pacing protocols, AI monitoring in real time
model_availability: Part of Quris’s internal AI-driven service/partnership

Organs/Tissues: Human neuronal tissue (iPSC-derived neurons/glia) for neurotoxicity or efficacy testing
Physiological/Pathological: Physiological baseline neuronal network; can detect excitotoxicity or seizure-like activity
Cell Source: iPSC-derived neurons, astrocytes, from diverse donors
Stromal Cells: Astrocytes act as supportive glia; no fibroblasts
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Potential linking or AI-based integration with other chips (BBB, etc.)
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, neural cells grown in 3D hydrogel or microfluidic well
3D Scaffold: Yes, 3D neural cluster with synaptic connectivity
Notable Features: Continuous sensor readouts of neuronal firing or stress signals, synergy with Quris AI for neuro-safety predictions
Plate/Format (Throughput): High-density microfluidic array with embedded neuronal activity sensors
Max Culture Duration: Days to a couple weeks for neural viability, stable enough to see chronic effects
Readouts - Live Imaging: Optional but main routine from integrated sensors or calcium imaging
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, for neurotransmitter or secreted factor detection
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible at endpoint, not typical in large screens
Readouts - MEA: Likely integrated electrode arrays measuring synaptic/electrical activity in real time
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes, real-time electrical activity or impedance sensors for neuronal viability/firing
Perfused: Microfluidic environment or partial flow for long-term culture
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated dosing & electrical stimulation, AI-driven data capture
model_availability: Internal Quris platform usage, accessible via collaboration

Organs/Tissues: Human brain microvascular endothelium + astrocytes/pericytes forming BBB
Physiological/Pathological: Physiological tight junction barrier; can assess pathological disruptions or drug permeability
Cell Source: iPSC-derived brain endothelial cells, astrocytes, pericytes from diverse donors
Stromal Cells: Pericytes as supportive cells; astrocytes as glial stroma
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Possible link to brain chip or other organ chips via microfluidics or AI-based synergy
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, hydrogel or ECM coatings to support endothelial-glial interface
3D Scaffold: A 3D arrangement, though can be parallel channels of endothelium plus astrocyte compartment
Notable Features: Tight junction expression, integrated sensor measuring barrier integrity and drug transport for CNS predictions
Plate/Format (Throughput): High-throughput microfluidic array with TEER-like or nano-sensor-based readouts
Max Culture Duration: Days to ~2 weeks for stable barrier function tests
Readouts - Live Imaging: Possible for junction staining or tracer leakage, but main routine from sensor data
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, can measure drug crossing or secreted factors on abluminal side
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: At endpoint for expression analysis, not typical in large screens
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes if needed for IHC of tight junction proteins
Readouts - TEER: Equivalent built-in sensor measuring barrier resistance in real time
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes, real-time detection of barrier changes, possibly chip-embedded electrodes
Dead Volume: Very small channels, minimal media usage
Perfused: Yes, a microchannel with flow simulating blood side, separate brain side
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated dosing, sensor feedback. AI tracks drug crossing
model_availability: Internal Quris platform usage via partner projects

Organs/Tissues: Human renal proximal tubule or glomerulus mimic for nephrotoxicity testing
Physiological/Pathological: Normal kidney filtration and reabsorption, used to detect pathological toxicity or injury
Cell Source: iPSC-derived kidney epithelial cells, or primary renal tubular cells (from Nortis tech)
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, tubular epithelial cells ± supporting cells; not typically including immune or endothelium unless specialized
Stromal Cells: Renal fibroblasts or mesangial cells optional, depending on model specifics
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Possible link to other Quris chips or data-based multi-organ PK modeling
Air–Liquid Interface: No, fluidic channel simulating renal tubule lumen
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, collagen or other scaffold forming tubular structure
3D Scaffold: Yes, microfluidic tubule geometry with epithelial lining
Notable Features: Predicts nephrotoxicity missed by animals, uses iPSC or primary cells in a microfluidic tubule environment
Plate/Format (Throughput): High-throughput microfluidic array licensed from Nortis, integrated into Quris system
Max Culture Duration: Up to 2 weeks, enough for repeated dosing or chronic kidney toxicity
Readouts - Live Imaging: Possible to visualize cell morphology or track fluorescent biomarkers of damage
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, measure secreted kidney injury markers (e.g. KIM-1), drug or metabolite levels in outflow
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Feasible at endpoint, not routine in large screens
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, fix tubule structure for histology if desired
Readouts - TEER: Kidney uses transport assays or barrier function readouts, may have integrated sensor for leak detection
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes, nano-sensors measuring barrier or cell stress in real time
Perfused: Yes, continuous flow simulating fluid in tubule lumen
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated fluid flow, dosing schedules, sensor-based feedback for toxicity detection
model_availability: Internal Quris platform usage from Nortis acquisition, available via Quris’s collaborations

Organs/Tissues: Human intestinal epithelium for absorption and GI safety studies
Physiological/Pathological: Healthy gut barrier, can identify GI toxicity or estimate oral bioavailability
Cell Source: iPSC-derived intestinal epithelial cells (multiple donors for genetic diversity)
Multiple Cell Types: Likely includes absorptive enterocytes + goblet cells; no immune or fibroblasts by default
Crosstalk with Other Tissues: Might link to Quris’s other chips for overall PK in future; or integrated via AI
Air–Liquid Interface: Unclear if partially used, possibly fully fluid approach in microfluidic format
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, supportive hydrogel or coated membrane for epithelial cell growth
3D Scaffold: 2D monolayer or 3D micro-lumens in chip, details not yet disclosed
Notable Features: Under development, extends Quris coverage to oral absorption & GI safety, high-throughput sensor-based approach
Plate/Format (Throughput): Likely microfluidic array, scalable to many donors/conditions
Max Culture Duration: Likely days to 2 weeks, enough for barrier formation & repeated dosing
Readouts - Live Imaging: Potential but main is sensor data for barrier integrity, cell viability
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, apical/basolateral compartments for absorption measurement
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, for end-of-run histology or IF
Readouts - TEER: Likely integrated to measure barrier function if akin to their BBB approach
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes, consistent with Quris’s overall approach
Perfused: Likely partially or fully perfused microchannels simulating intestinal flow
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Automated dosing, sensor tracking. Still in R&D phase
model_availability: Future model in Quris pipeline, not fully released
